Hello, noweb!
An exploration of literate Idris programming via noweb.

Eric Bailey

Abstract

What follows is an attempt at using noweb to write a literate program in Idris. While Idris provides some literate programming support of its own, it's rather basic (like Literate Haskell), and doesn't allow users to present code chunks out of order or do any sort of cross-referencing.

Table of Contents

  • Module Declarationsection.1
  • The main Functionsection.2
  • Chunkssection.3
  • Indexsection.4

Module Declaration

<hello>= [D->]
<Module declaration>

First, we declare the Main module, including a docstring, which is another noweb chunk, because we can. 

<Module declaration>= (<-U)
||| <Hello message>
module Main

The docstring above [The lines of an Idris docstring start with |||, and immediately precede the definition they document.] consists of the following message, which we'll also print later, using another noweb reference. 

<Hello message>= (<-U U->)
Hello, noweb!

The main Function

<hello>+= [<-D]
<main type signature>
<main definition>

main is an I/O action that doesn't return any value, i.e. 

<main type signature>= (<-U)
main : IO ()
Defines main (links are to index).

The action, when run, will output the message to stdout with a trailing newline. 

<main definition>= (<-U)
main = putStrLn "<Hello message>"

Chunks

  • <hello>: D1, D2
  • <Hello message>: U1, D2, U3
  • <main definition>: U1, D2
  • <main type signature>: U1, D2
  • <Module declaration>: U1, D2

Index

  • main: D1, U2
